Situation1: They maintain daily communication with their parents, sharing detailed updates and responding promptly to messages.
Expectation2: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation2: The mandatory daily pre-work safety briefing is starting in two minutes.
Story: My phone buzzes in my pocket just as I’m pulling on my hard hat. It’s my stepdad, again—he wants to know how I’m feeling after yesterday’s long shift, and if I remembered to eat breakfast. I know he expects a quick reply, maybe even a photo, just like every morning. It’s our thing, ever since Mom passed. But the foreman’s voice cuts through the clatter of boots and tools, calling everyone to the safety briefing. I glance at the clock: two minutes. If I’m late, I’ll get written up, maybe even sent home. The guys are already lining up, eyes on me, waiting. My phone vibrates again, a follow-up message. I can’t ignore my stepdad—he worries, and I promised I’d keep in touch. But if I text now, I’ll break site protocol and let my crew down. My heart pounds as I stand frozen between the two worlds, thumb hovering over the screen, hard hat in hand, the weight of both expectations pressing in from either side.
